elements.content: Three Zn-triazolate-dicarboxylate frameworks, namely, [Zn2(atz)2(ipa)] (1, Hatz = 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole, H2ipa = isophthalic acid), [Zn2(datz)2(ipa)] (2, Hdatz = 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole), and [Zn2(atz)2(oba)] (3, H2oba = 4,4′-oxobisbenzoic acid), have been synthesized by solvothermal reactions. Crystal-structure analyses demonstrated that 1–3 are isoreticular three-dimensional porous structures consisting of Zn-triazolate layers and dicarboxylate pillars. The major differences of three compounds are the lengths and orientations of the pillars. Thermogravimetry analyses and powder X-ray diffraction measurements showed that 1–3 have high thermal stability and good water stability. The adsorption properties of 1–3 were investigated by N2, CO2, and CH4 sorption experiments. Because 3 has exposed amino groups and distinct pore shape, it has the highest CO2 uptake and CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 selectivities at 273 K.

elements.content:
Three Zn-aminotriazolate-dicarboxylate frameworks with pcu topology and adsorption properties have been synthesized and characterized.

Introduction

Selective CO2 capture has attracted intensive attention for the landfill gas separation and the purification of natural gases. In the past decade, porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have gained intensive attention as functional materials because of their enormous structural variety and modifiable pore surface. Several strategies, such as open metal sites, polar functional groups, and extraframework cations, have been used to enhance the CO2 adsorption in PCPs. For example, Shimizu and co-workers reported a microporous framework [Zn2(atz)2(ox)] (Hatz = 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole; H2ox = oxalic acid) showing very high CO2 uptake and adsorption enthalpy, which can be attributed to the amino group. The small pore size also enhances adsorption affinity but limits the saturation uptake. Therefore, tuning the amino groups and pore size of this interesting structure should make better understanding of their impact on the CO2 adsorption properties. Actually, many similar three-dimensional (3D) Zn-triazolate-dicarboxylate pillared-layer frameworks have been investigated. For example, we got a series of nonporous structures with the Zn(atz) layers pillared by long and flexible aliphatic dicarboxylates, while a microporous material was obtained with the very short carbonate. Li et al. synthesized three porous frameworks with different pore sizes and shapes, by using linear aromatic dicarboxylates to connect Zn-triazolate layers, while Gao et al. used sulfate and 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazolate (datz–) to construct a porous framework. However, CO2 adsorption was not investigated for these compounds, probably because of their very small pore sizes and/or lack of the amino group.

Introduction

Selective CO2 capture has attracted intensive attention for the landfill gas separation and the purification of natural gases. In the past decade, porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have gained intensive attention as functional materials because of their enormous structural variety and modifiable pore surface. Several strategies, such as open metal sites, polar functional groups, and extraframework cations, have been used to enhance the CO2 adsorption in PCPs. For example, Shimizu and co-workers reported a microporous framework [Zn2(atz)2(ox)] (Hatz = 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole; H2ox = oxalic acid) showing very high CO2 uptake and adsorption enthalpy, which can be attributed to the amino group. The small pore size also enhances adsorption affinity but limits the saturation uptake. Therefore, tuning the amino groups and pore size of this interesting structure should make better understanding of their impact on the CO2 adsorption properties. Actually, many similar three-dimensional (3D) Zn-triazolate-dicarboxylate pillared-layer frameworks have been investigated. For example, we got a series of nonporous structures with the Zn(atz) layers pillared by long and flexible aliphatic dicarboxylates, while a microporous material was obtained with the very short carbonate. Li et al. synthesized three porous frameworks with different pore sizes and shapes, by using linear aromatic dicarboxylates to connect Zn-triazolate layers, while Gao et al. used sulfate and 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazolate (datz-) to construct a porous framework. However, CO2 adsorption was not investigated for these compounds, probably because of their very small pore sizes and/or lack of the amino group.

elements.content: In this work, we adopted two bent aromatic dicarboxylates, i.e., isophthalic acid (H2ipa) and 4,4′-oxobisbenzoic acid (H2oba), as a new type of pillar in combination with atz– and datz– to construct three new isoreticular porous Zn-triazolate-dicarboxylate frameworks (Figure ). The results demonstrated that the number of amino groups and length of the bent pillar ligands have remarkable effects on the pore surface and adsorption properties.

elements.content: Commercially available reagents were used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermo-gravimetric (TG) analyses were performed under N2 using a TA Q50 system. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å). Gas sorption isotherms were measured by a Belsorp MAX volumetric adsorption equipment. The MeOH-exchanged (MeOH = methanol) samples were desolvated under high vacuum at 373 K (2·MeOH) and 393 K (1·MeOH and 3·MeOH) for 10 h to remove the remnant guest molecules prior to measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

Commercially available reagents were used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermo-gravimetric (TG) analyses were performed under N2 using a TA Q50 system. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å). Gas sorption isotherms were measured by a Belsorp MAX volumetric adsorption equipment. The MeOH-exchanged (MeOH = methanol) samples were desolvated under high vacuum at 373 K (2⋅MeOH) and 393 K (1⋅MeOH and 3⋅MeOH) for 10 h to remove the remnant guest molecules prior to measurements.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2 ·6H2O (1.0 mmol, 0.298 g), H2ipa (0.5 mmol, 0.083 g), Hatz (1.0 mmol, 0.084 g), DMF (4 mL), MeOH (4 mL), and H2O (2 mL) was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel parr bomb at 130 °C for 72 h, which was then slowly cooled to room temperature. After decanting the mother liquor, the colorless crystalline product was rinsed three times with fresh DMF (5 mL × 3) and dried in air for 12 h (yield ≈ 80% based on Zn). Elemental Analysis (%) for C14.25H15.25N8.75O4.75Zn2 calcd: C, 33.18; H, 2.98; N, 23.76. Found: C, 33.01; H, 3.06; N, 23.85. For guest-free C12H10N8O4Zn2 calcd: C, 31.25; H, 2.19; N, 24.30. Found: C, 31.29; H, 2.22; N, 24.25.

elements.content:
These MeOH-exchanged samples were obtained by exchanging 1·g, 2·g, and 3·g with 10 mL of MeOH three times daily for three days.

X-ray Crystallography

Diffraction intensities were collected on a Bruker Apex CCD area detector diffractometer (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by the direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXTL program package. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. The disordered guest molecules could not be modeled and were treated by the SQUEEZE routine. Crystallographic data were summarized in Table .

Solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO3)2, Hatz or Hdatz, and H2ipa or H2oba in mixed solvent DMF/MeOH/H2O yielded three crystalline products, namely, [Zn2­(atz)2­(ipa)]·0.75DMF (1·g), [Zn2­(datz)2­(ipa)]·DMF (2·g), and [Zn2­(atz)2­(oba)]·DMF·H2O (3·g). Single-crystal structure analyses demonstrated that 1·g-3·g are all pillared-layer structures based on the Zn-triazolate layers and bent dicarboxylate pillars. If the dinuclear Zn2(atz)2 or Zn2(datz)2 unit is viewed as a 6-connected node, and the bent dicarboxylate is viewed as the linker, the coordination frameworks of 1·g–3·g can be simplified as noninterpenetrated pcu topologies (Figure ). The solvent molecules are all highly disordered. Because of the differences in the number of amino groups and the length of dicarboxylates, the shape of 2D Zn-triazolate layers, orientation of dicarboxylates, and the pore structures are remarkably different in 1–3.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Structures

Solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO3)2, Hatz or Hdatz, and H2ipa or H2oba in mixed solvent DMF/MeOH/H2O yielded three crystalline products, namely, [Zn2(atz)2(ipa)]⋅0.75DMF (1⋅g), [Zn2(datz)2(ipa)]⋅DMF (2⋅g), and [Zn2(atz)2(oba)]⋅DMF⋅H2O (3⋅g). Single-crystal structure analyses demonstrated that 1⋅g-3⋅g are all pillared-layer structures based on the Zn-triazolate layers and bent dicarboxylate pillars. If the dinuclear Zn2(atz)2 or Zn2(datz)2 unit is viewed as a 6-connected node, and the bent dicarboxylate is viewed as the linker, the coordination frameworks of 1⋅g-3⋅g can be simplified as noninterpenetrated pcu topologies (Figure ). The solvent molecules are all highly disordered. Because of the differences in the number of amino groups and the length of dicarboxylates, the shape of 2D Zn-triazolate layers, orientation of dicarboxylates, and the pore structures are remarkably different in 1-3.

elements.content: Because of the change of the ligand orientation, the solvent accessible voids in 2·g exhibits a 2D channel (void = 37.4%, with maximum and minimum aperture diameters 5.6 and 2.5 Å, respectively) running across the ab-plane. In 2·g, half amino groups point to the 2D channel, but only the hydrogen atoms are exposed on the pore surface, just similar to that in 1·g (Figure b). The other half of amino groups located on the wall of 0D isolated cavities. Compound 3·g possesses a wavy 2D channel system (void = 35.9%) with the maximum and minimum aperture diameters 4.7 and 3.3 Å, respectively. As shown in Figure c, the amino groups of atz– ligands are exposed on the pore surface of 3·g.

elements.content: TG curves of 1·g–3·g indicated that the guests escaped in the range of 180–270 °C and that the samples decomposed at about 420 °C. The relatively high temperature for removing the guests may be associated with the small aperture size and the larger guest molecule. To activate the samples more mildly, the samples were exchanged by MeOH to give 1·MeOH–3·MeOH. TG curves demonstrated that the MeOH guests could be completely removed below 80 °C (Figure S1, ). The PXRD patterns of the desolvated samples matched perfectly with the simulated ones. To further examine the thermal stability of all three samples, in situ variable temperature PXRD measurements were carried out for 1·MeOH–3·MeOH. The results indicate that the desolvated frameworks of 1–3 are stable up to 420, 120, and 150 °C (Figure S2, ). At 120 °C, 2·MeOH transfers to another crystalline phase, which collapses at 440 °C. The low thermal stability of 3·MeOH may be ascribed to the flexible feature of oba2–. We also measured the hydrothermal stability of 1–3, which demonstrated that the framework integrity could be retained in water at 50 °C even after 12 days (Figure S3, ).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability and Hydrothermal Stability

TG curves of 1⋅g-3⋅g indicated that the guests escaped in the range of 180-270 °C and that the samples decomposed at about 420 °C. The relatively high temperature for removing the guests may be associated with the small aperture size and the larger guest molecule. To activate the samples more mildly, the samples were exchanged by MeOH to give 1⋅MeOH-3⋅MeOH. TG curves demonstrated that the MeOH guests could be completely removed below 80 °C (Figure S1, ). The PXRD patterns of the desolvated samples matched perfectly with the simulated ones. To further examine the thermal stability of all three samples, in situ variable temperature PXRD measurements were carried out for 1⋅MeOH-3⋅MeOH. The results indicate that the desolvated frameworks of 1-3 are stable up to 420, 120, and 150 °C (Figure S2, ). At 120 °C, 2⋅MeOH transfers to another crystalline phase, which collapses at 440 °C. The low thermal stability of 3⋅MeOH may be ascribed to the flexible feature of oba2-. We also measured the hydrothermal stability of 1-3, which demonstrated that the framework integrity could be retained in water at 50 °C even after 12 days (Figure S3, ).

elements.content: The permanent porosities of 1–3 were verified by their reversible type-I N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K (Figure ), which gave apparent Langmuir surface areas of 671, 643, and 755 m2 g–1, and pore volumes of 0.24, 0.23, and 0.27 cm3 g–1, respectively. The experimental void volumes were calculated by assuming liquid pore filling at the saturated state. Corresponding structural information and adsorption analysis were summarized in Table . For comparison, the crystallographic pore volumes estimated from their crystal structures were 0.18, 0.27, and 0.28 cm3 g–1, respectively. Careful analyses revealed that the isotherms of 1 and 3 were two-step, while that of 2 exhibited the normal type-I shape. The pore volumes estimated from the first-step uptakes were 0.14 cm3 g–1 for and 0.16 cm3 g–1 for 3. Therefore, for 1, the first step belongs to normal adsorption, and the second step is attributed to the expansion of the framework. On the other hand, the first step of 3 might be caused by slight distortion/contraction of the empty host framework after desolvation and/or at low temperature, which recovers to the original state at the second step. It is worth pointing out that framework flexibility has not yet been reported for the known Zn-triazolate-dicarboxylate pillared-layer PCPs. To some extent, framework flexibility may enhance the adsorption selectivity of CO2 over other gases.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Properties

The permanent porosities of 1-3 were verified by their reversible type-I N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K (Figure ), which gave apparent Langmuir surface areas of 671, 643, and 755 m2 g-1, and pore volumes of 0.24, 0.23, and 0.27 cm3 g-1, respectively. The experimental void volumes were calculated by assuming liquid pore filling at the saturated state. Corresponding structural information and adsorption analysis were summarized in Table . For comparison, the crystallographic pore volumes estimated from their crystal structures were 0.18, 0.27, and 0.28 cm3 g-1, respectively. Careful analyses revealed that the isotherms of 1 and 3 were two-step, while that of 2 exhibited the normal type-I shape. The pore volumes estimated from the first-step uptakes were 0.14 cm3 g-1 for and 0.16 cm3 g-1 for 3. Therefore, for 1, the first step belongs to normal adsorption, and the second step is attributed to the expansion of the framework. On the other hand, the first step of 3 might be caused by slight distortion/contraction of the empty host framework after desolvation and/or at low temperature, which recovers to the original state at the second step. It is worth pointing out that framework flexibility has not yet been reported for the known Zn-triazolate-dicarboxylate pillared-layer PCPs. To some extent, framework flexibility may enhance the adsorption selectivity of CO2 over other gases.

To characterize the selectivities of CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2, CO2 sorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K and CH4 and N2 sorption isotherms at 273 K were also measured for 1–3 (Figure ). The CO2 uptakes of 2 (68.4 cm3 g–1) and 3 (80.6 cm3 g–1) at 273 K are relatively high. Although 3 has the highest CO2 uptakes among 1–3, its uptakes of CH4 and N2 are the lowest. Therefore, 3 has very high CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 selectivities. The uptakes and the selectivities calculated by the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) were listed in Table .

The unexpectedly low CH4 and N2 uptakes of 3 might be explained by a slight framework distortion from as-synthesized 3·g to guest-free 3, which remarkably reduces effective pore volume. Although the change of PXRD patterns from as-synthesized 3·g to guest-free 3 is very small (no obvious contraction of the host framework), local distortion of the framework that reduces the effective pore volume is still possible, which have been observed in other PCPs. The 77 K N2 isotherm of 3 also implies the presence of a narrow-pore phase. To obtain the direct evidence of structural transformation of the host framework, determining single-crystal structure of guest-free 3 may be the only viable method. Unfortunately, the single-crystallinity of 3 always became poor after desolvation.

elements.content: In comparison of CH4 (0 Cm2 and 3.8 Å) and N2 (4.7 × 10–40 Cm2 and 3.64 Å), CO2 (13.4 × 10–40 Cm2 and 3.3 Å) has a much larger quadrupole moment and smaller kinetic diameter. Therefore, the phase transition from the narrow-pore to the large-pore could be easily achieved by the CO2 adsorption. However, although 1 has a larger pore volume than that of 2 after the pore expansion, only the original pore volume (smallest among 1–3) before the expansion can be utilized for CO2 adsorption at room temperature below 1 bar (as seen from the normal adsorption isotherm shape). In other words, the sequence of effective pore volume for CO2 should be 3 > 2 > 1. Moreover, the amino groups in 3 expose effectively and further enhance the CO2 uptake of 3. Using the adsorption isotherms measured at 273 and 298 K (Figure S4, ), the enthalpies of CO2 adsorption at zero coverage were calculated to be 29.6, 28.9, and 31.9 kJ mol–1 for 1–3, respectively.

elements.content: The selectivity for CO2/CH4 mixture adsorption on 1, 2, and 3 were analyzed using IAST. The isothermal parameters were well fitted by the Langmuir–Freundlich method from the experimental pure adsorption isotherms of CO2 and CH4 (Figure S5, ). For the mixtures composed of CO2 (50%) and CH4 (50%), the selectivities are in the range of 7–10 for 1, 5–11 for 2, and 35–50 for 3 at 273 K (Figure ). Even when the gas-phase molar fraction of CH4 is at 95%, the CO2/CH4 selectivity of 3 at 273 K (>35) is among the highest reported values for PCPs.

For the mixtures composed of CO2 (17%) and N2 (83%) at 273 K, the selectivities are in the range of 50–60 for 1, 55–70 for 2, and 200–400 for 3. The calculated selectivity of 3 is 386 at 1 bar, being comparable to the highest values reported for PCPs functionalized with the open metal sites and polar groups.

elements.content: In summary, we have prepared three new microporous frameworks with the classic Zn-triazolate-dicarboxylate pillared-layer structure and demonstrated their N2, CO2, and CH4 adsorption properties. These microporous frameworks showed good stability even in water, and demonstrated high CO2 adsorption capacity and high selectivity for CO2 over CH4 and N2.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have prepared three new microporous frameworks with the classic Zn-triazolate-dicarboxylate pillared-layer structure and demonstrated their N2, CO2, and CH4 adsorption properties. These microporous frameworks showed good stability even in water, and demonstrated high CO2 adsorption capacity and high selectivity for CO2 over CH4 and N2.

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2 ·6H2O (1.0 mmol, 0.298 g), H2ipa (0.5 mmol, 0.083 g), Hatz (1.0 mmol, 0.084 g), DMF (4 mL), MeOH (4 mL), and H2O (2 mL) was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel parr bomb at 130 °C for 72 h, which was then slowly cooled to room temperature. After decanting the mother liquor, the colorless crystalline product was rinsed three times with fresh DMF (5 mL × 3) and dried in air for 12 h (yield ≈ 80% based on Zn). Elemental Analysis (%) for C14.25H15.25N8.75O4.75Zn2 calcd: C, 33.18; H, 2.98; N, 23.76. Found: C, 33.01; H, 3.06; N, 23.85. For guest-free C12H10N8O4Zn2 calcd: C, 31.25; H, 2.19; N, 24.30. Found: C, 31.29; H, 2.22; N, 24.25.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1·g possesses 1D channels (void = 26.6%) with the maximum and minimum aperture diameters of 5.5 and 2.8 Å, respectively. The amino groups of atz– ligands point to the ball-shape cavity, but only the hydrogen atoms rather than the nitrogen atoms are exposed on the pore surface (Figure a).

Because of the change of the ligand orientation, the solvent accessible voids in 2·g exhibits a 2D channel (void = 37.4%, with maximum and minimum aperture diameters 5.6 and 2.5 Å, respectively) running across the ab-plane. In 2·g, half amino groups point to the 2D channel, but only the hydrogen atoms are exposed on the pore surface, just similar to that in 1·g (Figure b). The other half of amino groups located on the wall of 0D isolated cavities. Compound 3·g possesses a wavy 2D channel system (void = 35.9%) with the maximum and minimum aperture diameters 4.7 and 3.3 Å, respectively. As shown in Figure c, the amino groups of atz– ligands are exposed on the pore surface of 3·g.

Thermal Stability and Hydrothermal Stability

TG curves of 1·g–3·g indicated that the guests escaped in the range of 180–270 °C and that the samples decomposed at about 420 °C. The relatively high temperature for removing the guests may be associated with the small aperture size and the larger guest molecule. To activate the samples more mildly, the samples were exchanged by MeOH to give 1·MeOH–3·MeOH. TG curves demonstrated that the MeOH guests could be completely removed below 80 °C (Figure S1, ). The PXRD patterns of the desolvated samples matched perfectly with the simulated ones. To further examine the thermal stability of all three samples, in situ variable temperature PXRD measurements were carried out for 1·MeOH–3·MeOH. The results indicate that the desolvated frameworks of 1–3 are stable up to 420, 120, and 150 °C (Figure S2, ). At 120 °C, 2·MeOH transfers to another crystalline phase, which collapses at 440 °C. The low thermal stability of 3·MeOH may be ascribed to the flexible feature of oba2–. We also measured the hydrothermal stability of 1–3, which demonstrated that the framework integrity could be retained in water at 50 °C even after 12 days (Figure S3, ).

Gas Sorption Properties

The permanent porosities of 1–3 were verified by their reversible type-I N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K (Figure ), which gave apparent Langmuir surface areas of 671, 643, and 755 m2 g–1, and pore volumes of 0.24, 0.23, and 0.27 cm3 g–1, respectively. The experimental void volumes were calculated by assuming liquid pore filling at the saturated state. Corresponding structural information and adsorption analysis were summarized in Table . For comparison, the crystallographic pore volumes estimated from their crystal structures were 0.18, 0.27, and 0.28 cm3 g–1, respectively. Careful analyses revealed that the isotherms of 1 and 3 were two-step, while that of 2 exhibited the normal type-I shape. The pore volumes estimated from the first-step uptakes were 0.14 cm3 g–1 for and 0.16 cm3 g–1 for 3. Therefore, for 1, the first step belongs to normal adsorption, and the second step is attributed to the expansion of the framework. On the other hand, the first step of 3 might be caused by slight distortion/contraction of the empty host framework after desolvation and/or at low temperature, which recovers to the original state at the second step. It is worth pointing out that framework flexibility has not yet been reported for the known Zn-triazolate-dicarboxylate pillared-layer PCPs. To some extent, framework flexibility may enhance the adsorption selectivity of CO2 over other gases.

cln_elements.content: Structures of the aminotriazole and bent dicarboxylic acids.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Structures of the aminotriazole and bent dicarboxylic acids.

cln_elements.content: (a) Pillared-layer structures of 1·g–3·g (dinuclear units, triazolate ligands, and dicarboxylates are simplified as cyan spheres, blue sticks, and red sticks, respectively. (b–d) Top views of the representative fragments of (b) 1·g, (c) 2·g, and (d) 3·g showing the different shapes of 2D Zn-triazolate layers and orientations of the dicarboxylate phenyl rings (highlighted in space-filling mode).
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Pillared-layer structures of 1⋅g-3⋅g (dinuclear units, triazolate ligands, and dicarboxylates are simplified as cyan spheres, blue sticks, and red sticks, respectively. (b-d) Top views of the representative fragments of (b) 1⋅g, (c) 2⋅g, and (d) 3⋅g showing the different shapes of 2D Zn-triazolate layers and orientations of the dicarboxylate phenyl rings (highlighted in space-filling mode).

cln_elements.content: Solvent (probe radius 1.2 Å) surface diagrams of 1·g (a), 2·g (b), and 3·g (c) viewed perpendicular (left) and parallel (right) to the 2D Zn-triazolate layers.
